reviewText: "Hawk of the Wilderness" comes from the late 1930's when Republic filmed nearly everything fresh, with their directors William Witney and John English. The star, Herman Brix/Bruce Bennett, had played Tarzan three years earlier, was muscular and physically up to the task, and yet projected a quiet assurance when delivering his lines. He also figured into three other recommended Republic serials:  "The Lone Ranger (1938)" as one of the candidates although not the eventual Lone Ranger, "Fighting Devil Dogs (1938)", and "Daredevils of the Red Circle (1939)".  Noble Johnson as Mokuyi make a rare appearance as a good guy. Republic was building their library at this point, filming new, and stands above and beyond much of  Universal product built on a platform of grainy old speeded up stock footage.

This serial is the best serial I watched on television in the 1950's.  I never missed an episode.  Too bad they haven't transferred it to a DVD.  Herman Brix/Bruce Bennett was a fine actor and not bad to look at either.

This is one I missed as a kid, I saw a different wildeness in my mind when reading other reviews, something more sub tropical than great north woods. "Hawk" is another version of the Tarzan, Bomba, Jungle Girl, etc myth, with shades of Jules Vern's mysterious version of an Iceland type island made verdent by hot springs. I had to get used to the northern California landscape and see this "island" as a very big place. The opening chapter is classic in both senses of the word. like Moses, like Superman. It was very well done. The acting is first rate, not "saturday"
kid stuff, and the human motivations are believable and honest. We lost Bruce Bennett this year, an inspiration and national treasure who lived the entire century. The story and characters both "develop", unusual in a serial, and are not "predictable" After adjusting to the big pine woods, I was really into this serial. Unfortunately, typical of the times, was the "comic" "superstitious" "freightened" black family servant, also used in "Daredevils of the Red Circle" Director Witney acknowledged it in his bio, but pointed out what was even worse, the virtual unemployment of black actors in Hollywood.

Republic Pictures present "HAWK OF THE WILDERNESS" (1938) (217 mins/B&W) (Dolby digitally remastered) --- is a 12-Chapter Republic Movie Serial starring Herman Brix, Ray Mala, Jill Martin, Monte Blue & Noble Johnson, relive those thrilling days week after week venue brought you to the theater, as you were mesmerized in your seat waiting for the final chapter ... exciting action within 12 episodes from the Republic Serials department, released in December 16, 1938, the plot line thus far with a volcano set to erupt on an uncharted jungle island, an expedition is mounted to rescue the local natives which are led by a mysterious jungle boy ... will this young man, reared by natives on a remote island, save his community from evil pirates, was originally titled "Lost Island of Kioga" ... the main character, "Kioga", was created by pulp writer William L Chester, "Kioga" is very similar to the character of "Tarzan", whom Herman Brix had also played on film in the 1935, Edgar Rice Burroughs produced serial "The New Adventures of Tarzan".  ... the once fabulous Republic Studio serial machine turned out true masterpieces of action during the late 30s and early 40s ... remember this serial from the Saturday double features at our neighborhood theater ... 12 breathtaking chapters come across with all the gusto Republic Studios has to offer.

Under William Witney (Director), John English (Director), Robert M. Beche (Associate Producer), Norman S. Hall (Screenwriter), Barry Shipman (Screenwriter), Rex Taylor (Screenwriter), William Lava (Original Score), William Nobles (Cinematographer), Edgar Lyons (Cinematographer), Edward Todd (Editor), Helene Turner (Editor) ------ the cast includes Herman Brix/Bruce Bennett (Kioga), Mala (Kias), Monte Blue (Yellow Weasel), Harley Wood (Beth ), Noble Johnson (Mokuyi), William Royle (Solerno), Tom Chatterton (Dr, Munro), George Eldredge (Allen Kendall), Patrick J. Kelly (Bill Bill), Dick Wessel (Dirk), Fred 'Snowflake' Toones (George),Tuffie the Dog (Tawnee), Tuffy the Dog (Tuffy), Chief John Big Tree (Medicine Man), Lane Chandler (Lincoln Rand Sr), Iron Eyes Cody (Storm Cloud), Ted Mapes (Henchman), George Montgomery (Tom), Jack O'Shea (Henchman)  ... great stunt work by the Republic stunt personnel Ted Mapes (stunt double: Herman Brix) --- don't leave the theater until the final chapter ... another winner from the vaults of Republic Serials --- this is a must watch for the serial buffs in all of us.

BIOS:

1. Bruce Bennett (aka: Herman Brix)

Date of birth:  19 May 1906 - Tacoma, Washington

Date of death:  Still Living

Special footnote, Herman Brix was a star shot-putter in the 1928 Olympics

he was picked by Edgar Rice Burroughs for his own production of

The New Adventures of Tarzan (1935/I), resulting in the Tarzan and the

Green Goddess (1938) After "Adventures" he made a number of serials for Republic,

including a Tarzan-like Kioga in Hawk of the Wilderness (1938), "Daredevils of the Red Circle" (1939),

"Hi-Yo Silver" (1940), changed his name to Bruce Bennett, made many movies after that, gaining fame

as a leading man in many Warner Bros. roles."Mildred Pierce" (1945/Joan Crawford),

"Dark Passage" (1947/Bogart & Bacall), and one of my favorite all time films

"The Treasure of the Sierra Madre" (1948/Bogart, Walter Huston, Tim Holt and Alphonso Bedoya as the bandit).

2.  Mala  (aka: Ray Wise)

Date of birth:  27 December 1906 - Territory of Alaska

Date of death:  23 September 1952 - Hollywood, California

Special footnote, Ray Mala hailed from Alaska, and portrayed Inuits and also Hawaiian characters in films.

appeared in more than 25 movies, such as "Eskimo" (1933), "Last of the Pagans" (1935),

"Robinson Crusoe of Clipper Island" (1936), "The Great Adventures of Wild Bill Hickok" (1938),

"Flash Gordon Conquers the Universe" (1940), "North West Mounted Police" (1940 and "Red Snow" (1952).

3. William Witney (aka: William Nuelsen Witney) (Director)

Date of birth: 15 May 1915 - Lawton, Oklahoma

Date of death: 17 March 2002 - Jackson, California

Special footnote, Witney broke into the business in 1933, working at Mascot, the leading producer

of low-budget serials, Mascot merged in 1935 to form Republic,Witney teamed with director John English

on many of the era's best serials, most of them highlighted by kinetic fight and chase scenes that helped

change the face of action moviemaking...Witney became a director at 21, he was Hollywood's youngest.

4. John English (Director)

Date of birth: 25 June 1903 - Cumberland, England, UK

Date of death: 11 October 1969 - Los Angeles, California

Special footnote, directing classic serials "Zorro Rides Again" (1937),

"Daredevils of the Red Circle" (1939), "King of the Royal Mounted" (1940),

"Adventures of Red Ryder" (1940), "Jungle Girl" (1941),"Adventures of Captain Marvel" (1941),

and "Captain America" (1944), worked closely with director William Witney over the years.

Hats off and thanks to Les Adams (collector/guideslines for character identification), Chuck Anderson (Webmaster: The Old Corral/B-Westerns. Com), Boyd Magers (Western Clippings), Bobby J. Copeland (author of "Trail Talk"), Rhonda Lemons (Empire Publishing Inc), Bob Nareau (author of "The Real Bob Steele") and Trevor Scott (Down Under Com) as they have rekindled my interest once again for B-Westerns and Serials --- looking forward to more high quality releases from the vintage serial era of the '20s, '30s & '40s and B-Westerns ... order your copy now from Amazon where there are plenty of copies available on VHS, stay tuned once again for top notch action mixed with deadly adventure --- if you enjoyed this title, why not check out VCI Entertainment where they are experts in releasing B-Westerns and Serials --- all my heroes have been cowboys!

Total Time: 217 mins on VHS ~ Republic Video ~ (7/18/1995)

I enjoyed the well put together story based on the William L Chester book, the good direction and beautiful locations. Much of the background is of Mammoth Lakes in High Sierra of Central California.

 Brix, who changed his stage name to Bruce Bennett in 1939, said he was completely exhausted at the end of the filming of HAWK having worked virtually nonstop for 3 days and nights to finish the 12 chapter serial.

 I enjoyed the performance of Noble Johnson as Mokuyi, Monte Blue as Yellow Weasle while recognizing Iron Eyes Cody, Lane Chandler and George Montgomery in bit roles. Mr. Mapes was noticed in some of the stunts. Harley Wood was credited as Jill Martin here.

 One must realize that the performances were pretty good considering the financial and time constraints imposed by the producers. Directors Witney and English could really orchestrate action and usually get it right in one take. Even Tuffy, the australian shephard-collie mix who played Tawnee was great.

 Some would rate this serial as one of the top 10. Because of Brix, the rest of cast, and the Mammoth Lakes location, and of course, the direction of Witney and English, I would agree..There is a kind of dignity found here in this 1938 production.

 Trivia:

 Noble Johnson (Mokuyi) was a man of color who founded the first black owned film production company and was a friend of Lon Chaney.

 Monte Blue (Yellow Weasle) was a silent film star and later had a role in Key Largo with Humphrey Bogart and Claire Trevor

 Mala was really part eskimo and well suited as Kias, the lame in Hawk of the Wilderness

 Brix/Bennett is alive and well going on 99 living in the Los Angeles area. He later became a successful realtor to the rich and famous in L. A. area before retiring in 1990

Hawk is not generally recognized as one of the great serials, but IMHO it's in the top ten. This is one serial with a story, not just "We're trying to collect all ten of the Scorpion's feet, or whatever." Strong direction and tight performances even from actors not generally admired, i.e., Mala, add up to a consistently entertaining twelve episodes of pure fun.
